name: heat production, hard coal coke, stove 5-15kW | heat, central or small-scale, other than natural gas | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2645/documentation

This dataset represents the production of heat from a 5-15 kW coal stove filled with 1 MJ of hard coal coke. The lifetime of the coal stove is 30 years, which corresponds to 1600 fully load hours per year. The heating value is 28.6 MJ/kg and the efficiency factor is 70%.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of hard coal coke.

This activity ends with produced heat at the coal stove filled with 1 MJ of hard coal coke. The dataset includes transport and all emissions to air as well as the ash disposal. The dataset doesn’t include emissions to water as it is assumed that the coal is stored in a covered storage area.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average technology installed in early 1990s. The efficiency factor of a coal stove is between 50% and 70%. Since the coal stove is installed in the room to be heated, losses occur especially through the large amounts of flue gas and through incomplete combustion. An efficiency factor of 70% is assumed. Since neither ventilators nor air supply pumps are required for hot water circulation, no auxiliary energy is needed.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Amount was scaled to 1.

flow.name: heat, central or small-scale, other than natural gas
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). From radioactivity of the elements.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Radon-220
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.

Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). From radioactivity of the elements.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Potassium-40
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.

Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Iron ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=PL
Estimation. It is assumed that 100% of the ash is disposed. The ash content is 10%. The density of dry ash is 400 to 650 kg/m3.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

defaultProvider.name: market for hard coal ash | hard coal ash | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/382:Waste treatment and disposal/3821:Treatment and disposal of non-hazardous waste

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). The emission data are taken from the literature reporting measurements performed at the end of the 1980s in Germany and are based on the composition of the coal.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Propylene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. From a small selection of analysis an arithmetic value is derived to calculate the composition of hard coal briquettes. The caloric value is 28.6 MJ/kg, the bulk density is 480-580 kg/m3, the water content is 6% and the ash content is 10%. Further values are 81.7% of carbonates, 0.9% of nitrogen, 0.7% of sulfur, 0.04% of chlorine, 0.005% of flour. 

Further references:
Fritsche U., Leuchtner J., Matthes F.C., Rausch L., Simon K.-H. (1992) Umweltanalyse von Energie-, Transport- und Stoffsystemen: Gesamt-Emissions-Modell Integrierter Systeme (GEMIS) Version 2.0. Darmstadt/Kassel.
Fritsche U., Matthes F.C. (1992) Analyse von Datenbasen zu klimarelevanten Emissionen in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Berlin/Darmstadt/Deutschland.
Hausen H. (Hsrg.) (1972) Thermodynamische Eigenschaften von Gemischen, Verbrennung, Wärmeübertragung. IV. Band Technik, 4. Teil, 6. Auflage, Berlin.
Ratajczak E.-A. (1987) Emissionsmessungen an kohlegefeuerten Hausbrandfeuerstätten, insbesondere im Hinblick auf gesundheitsgefährdende Abgasbestandteile. Band 1-3, Im Auftrag des UBA Berlin, Essen.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
EcoSpold01Location=RER
